summary: This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) memoranda, timelines, and updates regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes the initial press release, detailed suicide timeline, and multiple institutional responses to a psychological reconstruction report, addressing failures in procedures, staffing, documentation, and inmate management leading up to Epstein's death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: At approximately 6:30 a.m., inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York. Life-saving measures were initiated, and he was transported to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead. The incident was investigated as an apparent suicide.

events.title: Previous Incident/Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with abrasions on his neck and knee. Inconsistencies exist in staff reports about the object around his neck (string vs. orange cloth). A Special Investigative Services (SIS) threat assessment was inconclusive as to whether it was self-directed violence, a fight, or an assault.

events.title: Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC New York under pretrial status after being indicted for sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

events.title: Bail Denied
events.description: Epstein was denied bail, a significant disappointment noted in the psychological reconstruction as a stressor that likely challenged his adaptation to incarceration.

events.title: Last Day Before Death
events.description: Epstein met with attorneys throughout the day. In the evening, he was provided a social call by an IDO who reported he was in good spirits. His cellmate, Efrain Reyes, departed for court and did not return.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Report Dated
events.description: A psychological reconstruction of inmate Epstein's death was completed, leading to the institutional response memoranda from the Warden in January 2020.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, at approximately 6:30 a.m. and was later pronounced dead at a hospital. The FBI investigated the incident as an apparent suicide.

A psychological reconstruction identified numerous procedural failures, including inconsistent documentation of a prior incident on July 23, 2019, inaccurate SENTRY inmate cell assignments, lack of proper suicide watch protocols, and failure to secure log books as evidence after Epstein's death.
Epstein's cellmate at the time of his death was Efrain Reyes, a cooperator with the U.S. Attorney's Office. Previously, Epstein had been housed with Nicholas Tartaglione, a high-profile inmate.

The institutional responses from Wardens Licon-Vitale and Petrucci detail corrective actions taken, such as implementing new video review requirements, daily bed book audits, enhanced PSY ALERT procedures, and eliminating Psychological Observation status to reduce confusion.

The document reveals systemic issues at MCC New York, including seriously reduced staffing levels, improper training, and a lack of broad understanding among staff of sex offender-specific risk factors relevant to Epstein's case.
